label: Folder 18: Chase Letter
description: Letter to Helen Gardner McCormack from Pearl Chase (Plans and Planting Committee of the Community Arts Association) (Aug. 18, 1941) regarding request for publications about regional planning.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: State Headquarters  CAIFORNIA CONSERVATION  Council  County Headquarters  BETTER HOMES IN AMERICA  SANTA BARBARA COUNTY  ROADSIDE Council  Sponsors  THE SANTA BARBARA GARDENER  Arranges  GARDEN TOURS OF MONTECITO,  SANTA BARBARA AND  HOPE RANCH  planS AND planTING COMMITTEE  of the  Community Arts  Association  209 E. CANON PERDIDO STREET  SANTA BARBARA, CAIFORNIA  telephone 3698  August  18th,  1941.  Affiiated with  CAIFORNIA GARDEN ClubS, Inc.  CAIFORNIA ROADSIDE  Council  AMERICAN planning AND  CIVIC  Association  national CONFERENCE ON  STATE PARKS  national ROADSIDE Council  Cooperates with  THE GARDEN Club OF AMERICA  Miss Helen G. McCormack  Secretary, planning Commission  Carolina Art  Association  Gibbs Memoria Art Gallery  Charleston, South Carolina.  My dear Hiss McCormack:  I would ike to refer you to the Publications of the  American planning and Civic Associaltion, the American. Civic annual and  Civic Comment, These are maied to members. Dues are $5.00 a year.  Under separate cover I will send you some iterature  which may be of interest. A few of the items are old but it may interest  you to read them.  I also advise you to address the national Park service,  Department of the Interior,and ask for Publications deaing with the care  and restoration of Historic Monuments.  I am working now on the a Purisima Mission but that has  invoved cooperation of Federal government, state and county over a period  of seven years.  St. Augustine, Forida, has recenty attempted to preserve  some historic buildings and their experience may be interesting. The  Williamstown experiment is, of course, the outstanding accompishment in  this country; that of Taxeo in Mexico, another type of activity. Henry  Ford"s work in Dearborne, Michigan, is still another.  My one suggestion is not to be appaed by the amount of  work to be done but see if you can arouse wide-spread interest and the  support of people who can best hep you by making a small but compete and  charming demonstration. As your questions were general I trust that these  scattered comments will be hepfu.  Cordiay yours,    Pear Chase, Chairman  plans and planting Committee  PC:H   901 Union Trust Bdg.  Washington, D. C
